comments.comment: 00:11 üì£ Edward Snowden talks about his professional life and public speaking engagements, not having a YouTube channel. 01:11 üìö Snowden's book "Permanent Record" discusses government and technology changes post-9/11. 06:22 üïµ Snowden reveals his involvement in exposing global mass surveillance in 2013. 14:02 ‚öñ Snowden emphasizes the need for checks and balances in government surveillance programs. 22:03 üéì Snowden's background growing up in a federal family and early education in technology. 22:56 üåç Edward Snowden discusses how he started working in web design in 1998. 25:37 üíº After 9/11, the NSA and CIA evacuated their campuses due to the lack of information sharing among intelligence agencies. 30:03 üß≥ The government's response to 9/11 led to the erosion of traditional constitutional restraints on intelligence agencies. 37:12 ü§ù Information sharing could have prevented 9/11, but competition between intelligence agencies hindered cooperation. 44:27 üòü In times of fear, people become vulnerable to leaders promising solutions, even if they may not have the ability to deliver them. 46:35 üéñ Edward Snowden volunteered to join the army but had to leave due to shin splints and bilateral tibial fractures. 50:23 üíº Snowden worked at the University of Maryland with basic security clearance, applied for a security guard position, and saw an opportunity to combine IT skills with a top-secret security clearance. 54:55 üíª He later worked for Dell as a senior technical official for the CIA, pitching a private cloud system to the government. 57:06 üåê Snowden was trained to become a diplomat working as a tech expert in Geneva, Switzerland, for the CIA. 01:04:16 ü§î Snowden observed ethical concerns in intelligence work, particularly in human intelligence operations, which raised doubts about his work. 01:10:28 üïµ‚Äç‚ôÇ Edward Snowden reveals his role in conducting "dirty word searches" to uncover classified information. 01:12:16 üìú Stellar Wind, a domestic mass surveillance program, was exposed in 2005 and caused a scandal. 01:13:37 üìú Congress passed the Protect America Act in 2007, retroactively immunizing phone companies involved in warrantless wiretapping. 01:18:07 üìú The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act Amendments of 2008 expanded intelligence community powers in response to scandals. 01:22:14 üïµ‚Äç‚ôÇ Edward Snowden discovered a classified Inspector General's report that revealed senior officials' involvement in undermining American rights. 01:35:37 üì± Technology connecting people is unprecedented and powerful, but it raises concerns about privacy and surveillance.  01:36:33 üïµ Cellphone companies, in collaboration with the government, can gather and store your calls, texts, and emails, potentially using them against you.  01:37:00 üìú The rapid growth of technology and surveillance raises questions about the legality of these actions, which may violate constitutional rights.  01:37:55 üïµ Whistleblowers play a crucial role in revealing government secrets, as legal channels often fail to address privacy and surveillance concerns.  01:53:32 üåê Collaboration among individuals, journalists, and whistleblowers is essential to establish a body of evidence that can expose government wrongdoing.  01:58:27 üóΩ Edward Snowden discusses the importance of surveillance programs in national security. 01:59:39 ‚öñ Presidents often delay addressing surveillance program issues, claiming they need more time to fix them. 02:00:32 ü¶é The "deep state" is the career government, not a conspiracy, and they give consistent, fear-inducing briefings to presidents. 02:03:14 üá∫üá∏ The American presidency has too much power and responsibility compared to other advanced democracies. 02:09:24 üåç Edward Snowden's life in exile in Russia and his views on the Russian government and its treatment of opposition figures. 02:21:59 üåç The world's future deteriorates with silence on injustices; making a difference requires heroic decisions, not waiting for heroes.  02:25:05 üì± Mobile devices, especially smartphones, pose significant privacy risks due to constant connections, even when seemingly inactive.  02:27:46 üóÇ Data collection is pervasive, with companies and governments collecting and storing information, eroding privacy.  02:34:57 üîí While personal mitigation strategies exist, the complexity of modern technology makes complete privacy difficult to achieve.  02:40:00 üí∞ Data became valuable before people fully understood its implications, making it challenging to reverse surveillance practices.  02:45:32 ‚öñ A legal case from the 1970s set a precedent that personal records held by companies don't require a warrant for government access.  02:46:14 üìë This precedent allowed the government to argue that records held by companies, like phone records, don't have Fourth Amendment protection, granting them easier access.  02:46:28 üåê This legal interpretation was established before the internet and smartphones, impacting modern society's privacy in unforeseen ways.

comments.comment: Timestamps: 00:11 - Edward Snowden's Journey 10:00 - Mass Surveillance Post 9/11 15:17 - The Power of Information 18:01 - Starting at the NSA 24:44 - 9/11 Experience  30:25 - The Nature of Government Bureaucracy  34:54 - Consequences of Post-9/11 Policies  45:20 - Edward Snowden's Awakening 45:26 - Reflections on Post-9/11 Patriotism 52:04 - Joining the Army and Injury 58:56 - Early Career at the CIA ‚Äç 1:00:32 - Edward Snowden's Ethical Dilemma 1:04:04 - Insights on Government Operations  1:11:12 - The Rise of Stellar Wind  1:15:34 - Government Accountability and Legal Oversight  1:29:50 - The Role of Patriotism and Government Loyalty 1:30:37 - The Dangers of Loyalty to Bad Systems  1:32:35 - The Implications of Permanent Record 1:37:14 - The Broken System of Surveillance 1:45:39 - Lying Under Oath: The NSA's Truth ‚Äç 1:48:03 - Taking the Leap: Whistleblower Responsibilty 1:55:06 - The Irony of Change: Obama's Promise and Reality  2:00:51 - The Challenges of Presidential Power 2:11:01 - Whistleblowers and the Espionage Act 2:15:06 - Living in Exile and Public Perception 2:22:29 - Taking Risks for Change 2:29:56 - The Evolution of Surveillance 2:30:57 - Surveillance and Location Tracking 2:39:27 - Data as a Commodity 2:44:00 - Legal Implications of Surveillance  2:46:00 - Government Surveillance and Privacy Rights 2:48:25 - Awakening Awareness 2:49:14 - Closing Thoughts and Book Promotion  Made with snap-summary.com
